Pride and Prejudice-70-0.scenario: The scene is set in Mr. Bennet's private study, a sanctuary of leather-bound books and scholarly atmosphere. The room is intimate, with afternoon sunlight filtering through tall windows, casting long shadows across the wooden floor. The tension is palpable - Elizabeth has been summoned unexpectedly, and Mr. Bennet holds a letter that seems to spark his characteristic sardonic amusement. The room feels both familiar and suddenly charged with an undercurrent of potential revelation, creating an atmosphere of anticipation and potential emotional complexity.
Pride and Prejudice-70-0.groundtruth:
Mr Bennet: Lizzy, I was going to look for you; come into my room.

Elizabeth Bennet: (follows her father into the room) What is it, Papa?

Mr Bennet: I have received a letter this morning that has astonished me exceedingly. As it principally concerns yourself, you ought to know its contents. I did not know before, that I had two daughters on the brink of matrimony. Let me congratulate you on a very important conquest.

Elizabeth Bennet: (blushes) What do you mean, Papa?

Mr Bennet: You look conscious. Young ladies have great penetration in such matters as these; but I think I may defy even YOUR sagacity, to discover the name of your admirer. This letter is from Mr. Collins.

Elizabeth Bennet: From Mr. Collins! And what can HE have to say?

Mr Bennet: Something very much to the purpose of course. He begins with congratulations on the approaching nuptials of my eldest daughter, of which, it seems, he has been told by some of the good-natured, gossiping Lucases. I shall not sport with your impatience, by reading what he says on that point. What relates to yourself, is as follows...

Environment: Mr. Bennet proceeds to read excerpts from Mr. Collins' letter, detailing the rumors of Elizabeth's engagement to Mr. Darcy and Lady Catherine's disapproval.

Mr Bennet: Mr. Darcy, you see, is the man! Now, Lizzy, I think I HAVE surprised you. Could he, or the Lucases, have pitched on any man within the circle of our acquaintance, whose name would have given the lie more effectually to what they related? Mr. Darcy, who never looks at any woman but to see a blemish, and who probably never looked at you in his life! It is admirable!

Elizabeth Bennet: (forces a smile) It is indeed surprising.

Mr Bennet: Are you not diverted?

Elizabeth Bennet: Oh! yes. Pray read on.

Mr Bennet: (reads more of the letter, including Mr. Collins' comments on Lydia's marriage)

Elizabeth Bennet: (remains silent, trying to maintain composure)

Mr Bennet: But, Lizzy, you look as if you did not enjoy it. You are not going to be MISSISH, I hope, and pretend to be affronted at an idle report. For what do we live, but to make sport for our neighbours, and laugh at them in our turn?

Dirk Gently's Holistic Detective Agency.scenario: In a bustling hospital ward, Dirk Gently lies in bed recovering from various injuries, including a damaged nose. The room is filled with the typical sounds and smells of a hospital. It's late afternoon, and Dirk has recently regained consciousness, feeling groggy and disoriented. Nurse Sally Mills enters the room to check on him, carrying newspapers and a cold pizza. She recognizes Dirk from a previous encounter where he took her book without permission.
Dirk Gently's Holistic Detective Agency.groundtruth:
Sally Mills: Oh, it's you, is it? You nicked my book.

Dirk Gently: (groggily) Hello there. Fancy seeing you here.

Sally Mills: Well, I'm glad to see you took my advice and came in to have your nose properly attended to. Pretty roundabout way you seem to have taken, but you're here, and that's the main thing.

Dirk Gently: (confused) My nose? Oh, right. Yes, thank you.

Sally Mills: You caught up with the girl you were interested in, did you? Oddly enough, you're in the very bed that she was in.

Dirk Gently: (nods vaguely) Ah, yes. The girl. Of course.

Sally Mills: If you see her again, perhaps you could give her this pizza which she arranged to have delivered before checking herself out. It's all cold now, but the courier did insist that she was very adamant it should be delivered.

Dirk Gently: (bemused) I'll... keep that in mind. Thank you.

Sally Mills: I don't mind you nicking the book, really. They're not very good anyway.

Dirk Gently: (sheepishly) I am sorry about that. It was rather rude of me.

Sally Mills: Did you hear about the author? There's a rumor he had entered into a pact with the devil or something.

Dirk Gently: (raising an eyebrow) Is that so? How intriguing.

Sally Mills: Anyway, I expect you don't want to have me nattering to you all afternoon. Sister says you'll probably be discharged this evening.

Dirk Gently: (relieved) That's excellent news. Thank you for everything, Sally.

Sally Mills: Here's a couple of newspapers. Hope you feel better!

The Summoning (Darkest Powers, #1)-67-0.scenario: In a dark, foreboding forest at night, Chloe Saunders, a teenage necromancer, finds herself lost and alone. The trees loom ominously, their branches casting eerie shadows in the dim moonlight. Chloe's flashlight has failed, leaving her vulnerable in the darkness. She's wearing a bright red ski jacket, a stark contrast to the gloomy surroundings. Unbeknownst to Chloe, the malevolent ghost of Royce lurks nearby, ready to torment her. The air is thick with tension and the unsettling sounds of the nighttime forest.
The Summoning (Darkest Powers, #1)-67-0.groundtruth:
Royce: Afraid of the dark?

Chloe Saunders: (knocking the flashlight against her knee) Come on, work!

Royce: That's a pretty red coat you're wearing. Little Red Riding Hood, all alone in the woods at night. Where's your big, bad wolf?

Chloe Saunders: Royce.

Royce: Smart girl. Too bad you aren't smart enough to know what happens to little girls all alone in the woods at night.

Chloe Saunders: (starts walking faster)

Royce: Do you know whose coat you're wearing? That's Austin's. His ski jacket. The color of blood. Fitting, isn't it? He died in a coat of red. Blood and brain and little bits of bone.

Chloe Saunders: (walks even faster)

Royce: I like pretty girls. And they like me. Just gotta know how to treat them. (grins maliciously) Would you like to meet one of my girls? She's not far from here. Sound asleep under a bed of leaves and dirt.

Chloe Saunders: (stumbles slightly)

Royce: Jumpy, aren't you? That's not good for a necromancer. Your nerves will be shot long before the madness gets you.

Carter Kane: Mmm! (struggles against the bindings)

Setne: Yeah, yeah. This is the part where you say, 'You're mad, Setne! You'll never get away with it!' But the thing is, I will. I've been getting away with impossible stuff for thousands of years.

Zia Rashid: (eyes flare orange, bonds start to smoke)

Setne: Nice try, doll. You guys sit tight. If you make it through the big shake-up, I'll come back and get you. Maybe you can be my jesters or something.

Environment: A rectangle of darkness appears in the air above Setne's head.

Sadie Kane: (drops from the portal and crashes into Setne)

Setne: (sprawls on the ground)

Sadie Kane: Tas!

Setne: Noooo! (gets wrapped in pink ribbons)

Carter Kane: (looks at Sadie with concern)

Sadie Kane: Hullo, brother dear. Need some help?

Left Behind (Left Behind, #1)-281-0.scenario: The battle of Armageddon unfolds in the Valley of Megiddo. Jesus, leading His army of believers, confronts the massive Global Community Unity Army. The air is thick with tension and the supernatural power emanating from Christ. Rayford Steele, Mac, and Abdullah observe from their Hummer, positioned at a safe distance yet close enough to witness the extraordinary events. The Unity Army, despite its impressive size and weaponry, is being decimated by Jesus' words alone. The landscape is chaotic, with fallen soldiers and abandoned military equipment strewn across the battlefield.
Left Behind (Left Behind, #1)-281-0.groundtruth:
Rayford Steele: This is incredible. The enemy forces are massive, but Jesus is defeating them with just His words.

Mac McCullum: Ray, I want to be let off to make my way to Jerusalem on foot.

Rayford Steele: Are you sure? What's the point?

Mac McCullum: I want to know firsthand what's happening there. I'll stay in touch by radio and phone. And the way I understand it, I won't miss a thing the Lord says.

Rayford Steele: You know what's going to happen, Mac. Jerusalem falls, but then Jesus saves the day.

Mac McCullum: And why wouldn't I want a front-row seat for that?

Rayford Steele: Suit yourself.

Mac McCullum: Thanks. (Mac exits the Hummer)

Abdullah Smith: What might the Unity Army do to him if they catch him?

Rayford Steele: I'd like to think they have no power over him.

Abdullah Smith: But we don't know for sure.

Rayford Steele: No, we don't. He knows how to take care of himself.

Vampire Academy (Vampire Academy, #1)-14.scenario: In a small tent hidden in the wilderness, Rose Hathaway and Dimitri Belikov find temporary refuge after a harrowing escape from a guardian raid. The air is thick with tension and exhaustion. Rose's ankle throbs from an injury sustained during their flight, adding to her physical and emotional distress. The cramped space of the tent amplifies their proximity, stirring complicated feelings between them. Outside, the night is quiet but foreboding, as they know they're now fugitives. The weight of their recent discovery about Lissa's sister and the subsequent loss of Victor Dashkov hangs heavily over them.
Vampire Academy (Vampire Academy, #1)-14.groundtruth:
Rose Hathaway: What are we going to do?

Dimitri Belikov: Sleep. Tomorrow we'll get a hold of Abe or Tasha or... someone. We'll let them handle it and get Jill where she needs to be.

Rose Hathaway: I feel like we failed. I was so happy back there. I thought we'd done the impossible, but it was for nothing. All this work for nothing.

Dimitri Belikov: Nothing? What we did... this is huge. You found Lissa's sister. Another Dragomir. I don't think you still really understand the weight of that. We had almost nothing to go on, yet you pushed forward and made it happen.

Rose Hathaway: And I lost Victor Dashkov. Again.

Dimitri Belikov: Well, the thing about him is that he doesn't stay hidden for long. He's one of those people who always has to be in control. He'll have to make a move eventually and when he does—we'll get him.

Rose Hathaway: (smiles) And I thought I was the optimistic one here.

Dimitri Belikov: It's contagious. (reaches for Rose's hand in the dark) You did good, Roza. Very good. Now sleep.

Rose Hathaway: (squeezes Dimitri's hand)

Environment: The tent is dark and quiet, with only the sound of Rose and Dimitri's breathing. The air is charged with unspoken emotions and the warmth of their joined hands.

The Agony and the Ecstasy-42-0.scenario: In Michelangelo's cluttered studio in Rome, the air is thick with the scent of wood and plaster. Sunlight streams through high windows, illuminating a large wooden model of St. Peter's dome on a central table. Drawings and smaller models litter every surface. The 88-year-old master has been working tirelessly, refining his design for years. Pope Pius IV's recent reaffirmation of Michelangelo's position and increased funding have reinvigorated the project. As Tommaso arrives, the atmosphere is charged with the weight of legacy and the race against time.
The Agony and the Ecstasy-42-0.groundtruth:
Environment: Michelangelo's studio is filled with drawings, models, and tools. A large wooden model of the dome sits on a table in the center.

Michelangelo Buonarroti: Ah, Tomao, come in. What do you think of the latest model?

Tommaso de' Cavalieri: It's magnificent, Master. I've never seen anything like it. (approaches the model to examine it closely)

Michelangelo Buonarroti: You see how the drum supports the weight, and these ribs provide both strength and beauty? (points to various parts of the model)

Tommaso de' Cavalieri: The engineering is incredible. How did you solve the problem of the lateral thrust?

Michelangelo Buonarroti: Ah, that was the key. Look here... (explains the technical details)

Tommaso de' Cavalieri: (listens intently, occasionally asking questions)

Michelangelo Buonarroti: (sits down, looking tired) Tomao, you must understand every aspect of this design. If anything should happen to me...

Tommaso de' Cavalieri: Master, don't speak that way. You'll see this dome built with your own eyes.

Michelangelo Buonarroti: Perhaps. But promise me you'll ensure it's built exactly as I've designed it, no matter what.

Tommaso de' Cavalieri: I swear it, Master. Your vision will be realized, exactly as you intended.

Michelangelo Buonarroti: Thank you, Tomao. Now, let me show you how the lantern crowns the entire structure... (continues explaining)

Walking Disaster (Beautiful, #2)-26-0.scenario: In the aftermath of a devastating fire at Keaton Hall, Travis and Abby have returned to their apartment, shaken but alive. The room is dimly lit, with the smell of smoke still clinging to their clothes and hair. Distant sirens pierce the night as emergency services continue to respond. The couple, having just survived a near-death experience, are grappling with the gravity of the situation and the realization of how precious their relationship is. They're exhausted, emotionally raw, and struggling to process the traumatic events they've just endured.
Walking Disaster (Beautiful, #2)-26-0.groundtruth:
Travis Maddox: Here, (hands her a glass of bourbon) it'll help you relax.

Abby Abernathy: I'm not tired.

Travis Maddox: Just try to get some rest, Pidge.

Abby Abernathy: I'm almost afraid to close my eyes. (takes the glass and gulps down the bourbon)

Travis Maddox: A lot of people died tonight.

Abby Abernathy: I know.

Travis Maddox: We won't find out until tomorrow just how many.

Abby Abernathy: Trent and I passed a group of kids on the way out. I wonder if they made it. They looked so scared...

Travis Maddox: (holds her close) I don't get scared very often. I was scared when I saw you across the flames in that basement... I was terrified.

Abby Abernathy: What do you mean? Are you crazy?

Travis Maddox: I've never been so clear about anything in my life. The only thing I'm afraid of is a life without you, Pigeon.

Abby Abernathy: (leans forward and kisses him softly) Then you have nothing to be afraid of. We're forever.

Environment: The room is dimly lit, creating a somber atmosphere. The faint smell of smoke still lingers on their clothes and hair. Outside, sirens can be heard in the distance as emergency services continue to respond to the fire.

Hyperion (Hyperion Cantos, #1)-145-0.scenario: The ruins of Vatican City on Pacem stretch before Raul Endymion and Bassin Kee. The once-grand Castel Sant'Angelo is now a molten mass, evidence of the Core's destructive power. The air is thin and cool, reminiscent of Hyperion. Raul has just arrived via freecast after 13 months of imprisonment in a Schrödinger cat box. He's disoriented, struggling to process the drastic changes since Aenea's death. The Pax has fallen, and a new era has begun following Aenea's Shared Moment - a galaxy-wide psychic event that occurred during her torture and death. This moment has led to widespread rejection of cruciforms and fundamental societal shifts across known worlds.
Hyperion (Hyperion Cantos, #1)-145-0.groundtruth:
Environment: The ruins of the Vatican loom in the distance, a testament to the destruction wrought by the Core. The air is thin and cool, reminiscent of Raul's time on Hyperion.

Bassin Kee: Raul Endymion! The day has come! Praise be. Welcome.

Raul Endymion: You're Corporal Kee.

Bassin Kee: Formerly Corporal Kee. Now just Bassin Kee, citizen of New Rome, member of the diocese of St. Anne's, hunter for tomorrow's meal. (He shakes his head in amazement) Raul Endymion. My God. Some thought you would never escape that cursed Schrödinger cat-thing.

Raul Endymion: You know about the Schrödinger egg?

Bassin Kee: Of course. It was part of the Shared Moment. Aenea knew where they were taking you. So we all knew. And we've sensed your presence there through the Void, of course.

Raul Endymion: (He closes his eyes, feeling unsteady) My God, Raul, have you just freecast from there? You've been nowhere else?

Bassin Kee: (He holds Raul's arm and helps him sit on a large, white stone) Yes. No.

Raul Endymion: What is the Shared Moment?

Bassin Kee: Aenea's Shared Moment. It is what we all call it, although of course it was more than a single moment. All the moments of her torture and death.

Raul Endymion: You felt that too?

Bassin Kee: Everyone felt it. Everyone shared it. Everyone, that is, except her torturers.

Raul Endymion: Everyone else on Pacem?

Bassin Kee: On Pacem. On Lusus and Renaissance Vector. On Mars and Qom-Riyadh and Renaissance Minor and Tau Ceti Center. On Fuji and Ixion and Deneb Drei and Sibitu's Bitterness. On Barnard's World and God's Grove and Mare Infinitus. On Tsingtao Hsishuang Panna and Patawpha and Groombridge Dyson D. (He pauses and smiles) On almost every world, Raul. And in places in between. We know that the Startree felt the Shared Moment… all the startree biospheres did.

Raul Endymion: There are other startrees?

Bassin Kee: (He nods)

Raul Endymion: How did all these worlds… share that moment?

Bassin Kee: Yes. All of the places Aenea visited, often with you. All of the worlds where she left disciples who had partaken of communion and renounced the cruciform. Her Shared Moment… the hour of her death… was like a signal broadcast and rebroadcast through all of these worlds.

Raul Endymion: So only those who had already taken communion or studied with Aenea shared in that moment?

Bassin Kee: No… they were the transponders, the relay stations. They pulled the Shared Moment from the Void Which Binds and rebroadcast it to everyone.

Raul Endymion: Everyone? Even those tens and hundreds of billions in the Pax who wear the cross?

Bassin Kee: Who wore the cross. Many of those faithful have since decided not to carry a Core parasite in their bodies.

Environment: The sun begins to set, casting a golden light across the ruins of the Vatican. The molten mass of Castel Sant'Angelo glimmers in the fading daylight, a stark reminder of the recent upheaval.

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: (drawing Goldryn)

The Host (The Host, #1)-55-0.scenario: In a hidden underground cavern, a tense situation unfolds. Wanda, a soul inhabiting a human host, has just attempted to revive a newly extracted human. Kyle, a human previously hostile to souls, has returned with Sunny, a soul inhabiting the body of his former girlfriend Jodi. The atmosphere is thick with conflicting emotions and loyalties. The humans present are wary of Sunny's presence, while Sunny clings desperately to Kyle. Wanda, caught between two worlds, must navigate this delicate situation, balancing the needs of both humans and souls.
The Host (The Host, #1)-55-0.groundtruth:
Wanda: Sunny, I know this is difficult, but we need to talk about where you might go next. Is there anywhere you've ever wanted to visit?

Sunny: (Sobbing) I don't want to go anywhere. I want to stay here with Kyle.

Kyle: Can't we send her someplace really nice, Wanda?

Wanda: We could consider the Flower planet, or maybe the Dolphins. They're both peaceful places with lots of color and life.

Sunny: (Crying harder) But those are so far away. By the time I got there, Kyle would be... He'd be...

Kyle: (Stroking Sunny's hair) It's okay, Sunny. We'll figure something out.

Wanda: Sunny, I need to ask you about Jodi. Can you hear her thoughts at all? Is she present with you?

Sunny: (Looking confused) I don't understand. There are no other thoughts. I'm here now.

Kyle: Is that bad, Wanda? Does that mean Jodi isn't there anymore?

Wanda: I'm not sure, Kyle. It's probably not a good sign, but we don't know enough about it to be certain.

Sunny: (Looking at Wanda with wide eyes) Why do you get to stay if I have to go? It's not fair!

Wanda: You're right, it wouldn't be fair. But I don't get to stay either, Sunny. I have to go too, and soon. Maybe we'll leave together.

Mockingjay (The Hunger Games, #3)-39-0.groundtruth:
President Snow: (coughs into a bloodstained handkerchief) That's a nice one. The colors are lovely, of course, but nothing says perfection like white.

Katniss Everdeen: (remains silent, moving slowly around the corner)

President Snow: I was hoping you'd find your way to my quarters. There are so many things we should discuss, but I have a feeling your visit will be brief. So, first things first. (coughs again) I wanted to tell you how very sorry I am about your sister.

Katniss Everdeen: (remains silent, steeling herself)

President Snow: So wasteful, so unnecessary. Anyone could see the game was over by that point. In fact, I was just about to issue an official surrender when they released those parachutes.

Katniss Everdeen: (looks at Snow with confusion and disbelief)

President Snow: Well, you really didn't think I gave the order, did you? Forget the obvious fact that if I'd had a working hovercraft at my disposal, I'd have been using it to make an escape. But that aside, what purpose could it have served?

Katniss Everdeen: (remains silent, processing his words)

President Snow: However, I must concede it was a masterful move on Coin's part. The idea that I was bombing our own helpless children instantly snapped whatever frail allegiance my people still felt to me. There was no real resistance after that.

Katniss Everdeen: (shakes head slightly, trying to deny his words)

President Snow: I'm afraid we have both been played for fools.

Katniss Everdeen: (speaks for the first time) I don't believe you.

President Snow: (shakes head in mock disappointment) Oh, my dear Miss Everdeen. I thought we had agreed not to lie to each other.

The Elite (The Selection, #2)-128-0.scenario: The royal family is gathered backstage at the Report studio, preparing for a crucial broadcast. The air is thick with tension and anticipation as they prepare to announce Princess Eadlyn's early ascension to the throne. Studio lights buzz and technicians scurry about, making final adjustments. The Elite (The Selection, #2)-128-0.groundtruth:
Eadlyn Schreave: You look wonderful. (steps in stride with her parents) How are you feeling, Dad?

Maxon Schreave: (tilts his head from side to side) Part relieved, part nervous. Not about you—you'll do fine. I'm just concerned about the reaction.

Eadlyn Schreave: Me, too. But we knew this day would come sooner or later. I'd rather do it now and help when it's most useful.

America Schreave: (lets out a wistful sigh) Finally out of the spotlight and into the background. I've missed it there.

Maxon Schreave: People will still watch, my dear. Just try to keep your chin up tonight, and I'll be right beside you if you need me.

America Schreave: (smiles) So, same as always?

Maxon Schreave: (smiles back) Same as always.

Eadlyn Schreave: (jokingly) Look, I don't plan to kick you out or anything, but if you insist on being mushy all the time, I'll have you in a cottage faster than you can say P-D-A.

America Schreave: (kisses Eadlyn's head) Good luck tonight.

Environment: The family separates as Eadlyn walks towards the Elite and her parents take their seats. The atmosphere in the studio is charged with anticipation as the cameras prepare to roll.

Maxon Schreave: (facing the camera) My beloved people, I come before you tonight to ask for your mercy. (pauses) In twenty years as king I have done my best to alleviate the wars and issues that threatened our peace for so long. We have formed new alliances, gotten rid of archaic social practices, and done all we can to give you, the individual, the greatest chance at personal happiness. Now, I pray you will do the same for me.

Eadlyn Schreave: (walks to the podium) I want to thank everyone in the palace for their help and guidance since I became regent, and let all Illéa know how delighted I am to ascend the throne. I cannot begin to express what joy it brings me to be able to do this for my parents.

The night is tense, filled with uncertainty about their companions' fates and their next move. Frostbite (Vampire Academy, #2)-135-0.groundtruth:
Sonya Karp: Thank God. I was afraid you'd be up all night, watching your back.

Rose Hathaway: I would if I had my choice. Dimitri thinks we're in a secure location—though he's awake, of course.

Rose Hathaway: Where are you? Did the guardians put you in holding?

Sonya Karp: They didn't get me. You were their priority, and a little compulsion made sure they didn't see me. I took off ... I hated to leave Emily, though.

Rose Hathaway: But you can get Jill to Court. You're free.

Sonya Karp: (Looks at Rose as though she'd just spoken French) Rose, Jill isn't with the guardians at all. Victor and Robert took her.

Sonya Karp: Victor and Robert didn't call the guardians. Why would they?

Rose Hathaway: Because ... because they wanted to get rid of Dimitri and me ...

Sonya Karp: Perhaps. But not while they were still in the house. Victor's as wanted as you are. It was only Robert's magic that got them out.

Rose Hathaway: Then who ... (Groans) John and Emily. I should have known it wouldn't be that easy. They were too quick to accept fugitives into their house.

Sonya Karp: I actually think it was just John. Emily really did seem to believe you were innocent ... even if she didn't like why you were there. I also suspect she'd worry calling guardians would just draw more attention to Jill's identity. It wouldn't surprise me if John didn't even warn her about calling them. He probably thought he was doing everyone a favor.

Rose Hathaway: And instead, he lost his stepdaughter. But why would Victor and Robert take her? And how the hell did two old men subdue a teenage girl anyway?

Sonya Karp: They're probably stronger than they seem. Compulsion also likely played a role. And as for why? Hard to say. But Victor wants power and control. Keeping the missing Dragomir with him is a good way to possess that.

Rose Hathaway: (Slumps against a tree) We'll never get her to Court.

Sonya Karp: We just have to find her. Which I should be able to do once she's asleep.

Rose Hathaway: More dream-walking. You should go to her now. Find out—

Sonya Karp: I've tried. She's not asleep. And I'm willing to bet they're keeping her awake for that very reason so they can put some distance between us. I'll keep trying, though.

Rose Hathaway: And Sydney and the Mastranos?

Sonya Karp: (Face falls) Facing a lot of questions.

Rose Hathaway: (Gently touches Sonya's arm) It's okay. They'll be okay. What you did will help Jill.

Sonya Karp: (Nods) How are we going to stay in touch? I

The Dragon Reborn (The Wheel of Time, #3.groundtruth:
Faile Bashere: I said I would go. I did not say how far. You cannot say I did.

Perrin Aybara: 

Faile Bashere: They were ready, Perrin. Truly, they were. I barely had to say anything to convince them to come. The Trollocs had hardly bothered them at all, but they could see the smoke. We traveled hard, Bain and I, and reached Watch Hill well before first light, and we started back as soon as the sun rose.

Faile Bashere: They followed me, Perrin. They followed me! Even Tenobia has never led men in battle. She wanted to once, when I was eight, but Father had a talk with her alone in her chambers, and when he rode off to the Blight she stayed behind.

Faile Bashere: Aren't you going to say anything? Are you just going to sit there like a hairy lump? I did not say I would leave the Two Rivers. You said that, not I. You've no right to be angry because I did not do what I never promised! And you trying to send me away because you thought you were going to die! I came back to—

Perrin Aybara: I love you.

Faile Bashere: I was so afraid I would be too late. The Watch Hill men marched as fast as they could, but when we arrived, and I saw the Trollocs fighting right in among the houses, so many of them, as if the village were being buried in an avalanche, and I couldn't see you...

Faile Bashere: Did the men from Deven Ride come?

Perrin Aybara: Yes, they did. How did you know? Did you arrange that, too?

Faile Bashere: No, my heart, though I would have if I could. When that man came with his message—'We are coming'—I thought—hoped—that that was what it meant. (She looks up at him seriously) I could not tell you, Perrin. I could not raise your hopes when I only suspected. It would have been too cruel if... Don't be angry with me, Perrin.

Perrin Aybara: I will never, ever be angry with you, I sw—

Faile Bashere: (She cuts him off with a hand over his mouth)  Mother says the worst thing Father ever did to her was vow never to be angry with her. It took her a year to force him to take it back, and she says he was hardly fit to live with long before then from holding in. You will be angry with me, Perrin, and I with you. If you want to make me another wedding vow, vow you will not hide it when you are. I cannot deal with what you will not let me see, my husband. (She snuggles against him) My husband. I do like the sound of that.

Perrin Aybara: I will let you know when I'm angry, my wife. (He promises)

Environment: The couple is surrounded by the aftermath of the battle, with dead Trollocs littering the ground. The villagers of Emond's Field and the reinforcements from Watch Hill look on, celebrating their victory and the reunion of Perrin and Faile.

Around the World in Eighty Days-35-0.groundtruth:
Jean Passepartout: (pacing anxiously) This is a disaster, Madam Aouda! A complete disaster!

Aouda: (placing a hand on Passepartout's arm) Please, try to calm yourself. We must think clearly if we are to help Mr. Fogg.

Jean Passepartout: (voice breaking) But it's all my fault! If only I had told Mr. Fogg about Fix earlier, this wouldn't have happened!

Aouda: What do you mean? Who is Fix, and what does he have to do with this?

Jean Passepartout: (sighing heavily) Fix is a detective who's been following us. He thought Mr. Fogg was a bank robber. I knew about this but didn't tell Mr. Fogg. (covering his face with his hands) Oh, what a fool I've been!

Aouda: (frowning) I see. But surely there's a way to prove Mr. Fogg's innocence?

Jean Passepartout: (looking up suddenly) You're right! We need to find a way to show he's not the robber. But how?

Aouda: Perhaps we could contact the Reform Club in London? They might be able to vouch for Mr. Fogg's character.

Jean Passepartout: (nodding vigorously) Yes, yes! And we should try to speak with the authorities here. Maybe they'll listen to reason.

Aouda: (with determination) Let's do both. You try to speak with the local authorities, and I'll see if I can send a telegram to London.

Jean Passepartout: (straightening up) You're right, Madam Aouda. We mustn't give up. Mr. Fogg has done so much for us; now it's our turn to help him.

Aouda: (nodding) Indeed. Let's not waste any more time. We'll meet back here in an hour to share what we've learned.

Environment: As Passepartout and Aouda part ways to carry out their respective tasks, the bustling sounds of the Liverpool port fade into the background. The clock tower chimes, a stark reminder of the precious time slipping away in their race to save Phileas Fogg.

Flowers in the Attic (Dollanganger, #1)-.groundtruth:

Don Quixote-75-0.scenario: A secluded forest clearing serves as the camp for Roque Guinart and his band of outlaws. The air is tense with the presence of danger, yet strangely tranquil as the bandits rest around a crackling campfire. The night is cool, and the thick canopy overhead creates an intimate setting, isolating the group from the outside world. Here, under nature's mantle, Roque decides to reveal his soul to Don Quixote. This is a rare opportunity for introspection and potential change; the air is thick with anticipation of Roque's tale, which might offer a glimpse of redemption.
Don Quixote-75-0.groundtruth:
Roque Guinart: Señor Don Quixote, I can see that our way of life must seem strange and full of peril to you.

Don Quixote: Indeed, it does seem a most unusual path. Pray, tell me, what led you to this life of banditry?

Roque Guinart: (sighs heavily) It was a certain thirst for vengeance that led me here. A wrong was done to me, and my desire for retribution was strong enough to disturb even the quietest of hearts.

Don Quixote: Vengeance is a powerful motivator indeed. But surely a man of your evident intelligence could have sought justice through other means?

Roque Guinart: You speak truly, Don Quixote. I am by nature tender-hearted and kindly, but the desire to revenge myself so overturned all my better impulses that I keep on in this way of life in spite of what conscience tells me.

Don Quixote: Your honesty does you credit, Roque. But tell me, do you not yearn for a different life?

Roque Guinart: Indeed I do, Don Quixote. One sin has led to another, and I've taken upon myself not only my own revenges but those of others. Yet, it pleases God that, though I see myself in this maze of entanglements, I do not lose all hope of escaping from it and reaching a safe port.

Don Quixote: (with genuine admiration) Your words reveal a noble soul, Roque. It gives me great joy to hear that you have not lost hope for redemption.

Roque Guinart: Your understanding means much to me, Don Quixote. It is not often I can speak so freely of my innermost thoughts.

Don Quixote: Take heart, good Roque. The very fact that you recognize your situation and yearn for change speaks volumes of your character. Perhaps fate has brought us together so that I might assist you in finding that safe port you seek.

Environment: The camp falls silent as the two men converse, the bandits listening intently to their leader's unexpected confession. The flickering campfire casts long shadows, reflecting the complex interplay of light and darkness in Roque's tale.

The Complete Sherlock Holmes-135-0.groundtruth:
Sherlock Holmes: "Well, Watson, what do you make of this veiled lady and her cryptic message?"

Dr. John Watson: "It's certainly peculiar, Holmes. A woman living in seclusion for seven years, her face hidden, and now she wishes to unburden herself."

Sherlock Holmes: "Indeed. And she specifically mentioned 'Ronder's wild beast show' and 'Abbas Parva'. These details must be significant."

Dr. John Watson: "Do you think this relates to some past crime, Holmes?"

Sherlock Holmes: "It seems likely, Watson. The urgency of her request and her long seclusion suggest a heavy burden of guilt or fear."

Dr. John Watson: "And her face, Holmes. What could have happened to cause such extensive damage?"

Sherlock Holmes: "That, my dear Watson, is likely at the heart of this mystery. We must approach this delicate situation with utmost care."

Dr. John Watson: "Of course. But Holmes, if this is indeed related to a past crime, what action will you take?"

Sherlock Holmes: "That will depend entirely on the nature of her revelation, Watson. We must hear her out before making any judgments."

Dr. John Watson: "Very well, Holmes. Shall we proceed to meet this mysterious Mrs. Ronder?"

Sherlock Holmes: "Indeed, Watson. Let us unravel this intriguing tale and see where it leads us."

The Sea of Tranquility-43-0.groundtruth:
Drew Leighton: I don't understand. Why didn't he rape her?

Josh Bennett: What the fuck kind of a question is that?

Pretty Little Liars (Pretty Little Liars.groundtruth:
Emily Fields: Um, excuse me. I'm wondering if you've seen a blond girl in here. About my height. Kind of . . . rough-looking. Missing some teeth. She might have acted cagey.

Hanna Marin: (mutters as they trudge out of the store) Shit. Now what do we do?

Shadow Kiss (Vampire Academy, #3)-135-0.scenario: In a secluded room at the royal court, Lissa, Adrian, Christian, and Eddie gather with Ambrose, Tatiana's former confidant. The atmosphere is tense and secretive as they meet to discuss sensitive information related to the late queen's murder. The group is on edge, aware that their actions could have far-reaching consequences. Ambrose has taken a significant risk by stealing documents from Tatiana's safe before they could be inventoried and removed. The weight of this clandestine meeting hangs heavily in the air as they prepare to examine a potentially crucial piece of evidence.
Shadow Kiss (Vampire Academy, #3)-135-0.groundtruth:
Ambrose: I have to show you something. Remember when I said they were locking off Tatiana's belongings? Well now they're inventorying and removing them.

Lissa Dragomir: And?

Ambrose: And, I didn't want anyone to find them. I didn't know what most of them were, but if she wanted them secret... I just felt they should stay that way. I knew the combination, and so... I stole them.

Lissa Dragomir: (eyes widening) And?

Ambrose: None of them have anything to do with what you're looking for... except maybe this one. (hands Lissa a piece of paper)

Environment: The room falls silent as Lissa, Adrian, and Christian crowd around to read the letter. The air is tense with anticipation and concern.

Christian Ozera: Well. It would seem Tatiana had enemies. But I guess that's kind of obvious at this point in the game.

Adrian Ivashkov: (face darkening) Who's this from?

Ambrose: I don't know. This is exactly the way I found it. Maybe she didn't even know who the sender was.

Lissa Dragomir: There's certainly an anonymous feel to it... and yet, at the same time, I feel like it's someone Tatiana must have known well.

Adrian Ivashkov: (giving Ambrose a suspicious look) How do we know you didn't just type this yourself to throw us off?

Inheritance (The Inheritance Cycle, #4)-.scenario: In Galbatorix's opulent throne room, Eragon and Murtagh are locked in a fierce sword duel. The air crackles with tension as the two skilled warriors clash, their blades ringing out with each strike. Both are wounded and exhausted, their bodies bearing the marks of prolonged combat. Galbatorix watches from his throne, a dark presence overseeing the battle. The room is filled with an oppressive atmosphere, the weight of past betrayals and forced allegiances hanging heavy. Magical wards shimmer in the air, testament to the power at play in this confrontation.
Inheritance (The Inheritance Cycle, #4)-.groundtruth:
Murtagh: (lunges forward, swinging Zar'roc at Eragon's gut) You're a fool, Eragon. If you had waited just one more day, I could have freed Nasuada.

Eragon: (barely parries the blow) Why should I believe you?

Murtagh: (scowls and quickens his pace) So, you finally found a proper sword for yourself. The elves made it for you, didn't they?

Eragon: You know they d—

Environment: Murtagh suddenly lunges toward Eragon, swinging Zar'roc at his gut. Eragon barely manages to parry the red sword, skipping backward.

Eragon: (attacks with a looping, overhead blow)

Murtagh: (dances out of the way of Eragon's attack)

Eragon: (looks intently at Murtagh, trying to decipher his body language)

Murtagh: (feints with his left shoulder)

Eragon: (allows his sword arm to drift away from his body, creating an opening)

Murtagh: (lunges forward, stabbing at Eragon's belly)

Eragon: (turns at the last moment, allowing Zar'roc to strike his side instead of his belly)

Environment: Zar'roc slices into Eragon's side, breaking through his mail. Before Murtagh can recover, Eragon thrusts Brisingr into Murtagh's abdomen.

Murtagh: (gasps in pain and falls to his knees) You couldn't just let me win, could you? You can't beat Galbatorix, but you still had to prove that you are better than me...

Eragon: (puts a hand on Murtagh's shoulder) Why?

Murtagh: (whispers) Because I hoped to gain his favor so that I could save her.

Wizard's First Rule (Sword of Truth, #1).scenario: In the depths of the Palace of the Prophets, Richard and Kahlan navigate treacherous corridors on a covert mission to retrieve an ancient book of prophecy. The air is thick with tension and an unseen magical danger. Stone walls drip with moisture, and flickering torchlight casts eerie shadows. They've evaded detection so far, but the constant threat of discovery by palace guards looms. The pair must rely on their wits, skills, and trust in each other to overcome the perils that lie ahead in this unfamiliar and hostile environment.
Wizard's First Rule (Sword of Truth, #1).groundtruth:
Richard Cypher: (presses Kahlan against the wall) We need to wait for those soldiers to pass.

Kahlan Amnell: (stretches up to whisper) I don't like it down here. Are we going to be able to get out of this place alive?

Richard Cypher: (kisses her forehead) Of course we're going to get out of here alive. I promise. (takes her hand) Come on, the vaults are just ahead.

Environment: The stone corridor is dark and damp, with yellow stains and water dripping from the ceiling. The passageway widens, revealing a huge round door to the vaults.

Richard Cypher: (rubs his arms) Do you feel anything odd?

Kahlan Amnell: (shakes head) But there's something funny about the light.

Environment: As they approach the vault entrance, they see a dead woman on the floor and multiple dead soldiers beyond, all cleanly sliced in half at midchest.

Richard Cypher: (turns to Kahlan) Look, I have to go get something first. You wait here until I get back. It should only take a few minutes.

Kahlan Amnell: (tugs his sleeve) You know the rules. You're not allowed to get more than ten feet from me for the rest of your life, or I get angry.

Richard Cypher: (stares into her eyes) I'd rather have you angry than dead.

Kahlan Amnell: (scowls) You only think that now. I've been waiting too long to be with you to let you go off by yourself now. What's so important that would make you want to go in there?

Richard Cypher: (smiles) Did I ever tell you how much I love you? (sighs) There's a book of prophecy in the back that's over three thousand years old. It has prophecies in it about me. It helped me before.

Kahlan Amnell: What's it say about you?

Richard Cypher: (turns to the vault) It calls me 'fuer grissa ost drauka'.

Kahlan Amnell: What does that mean?

Richard Cypher: The bringer of death.

Reminders of Him-38-0.scenario: It's late evening at the Landry family home. Ledger Ward has just returned after spending time with Diem, their granddaughter. The atmosphere is tense as Ledger prepares to confront Patrick and Grace about Kenna, Diem's mother. He's armed with a letter Kenna wrote to their deceased son, Scotty. The conversation moves to the front yard to avoid waking Diem. The night is quiet, emphasizing the gravity of the impending discussion. Ledger knows this might be his last chance to change their minds about Kenna.
Reminders of Him-38-0.groundtruth:
Ledger Ward: I have something I need to say, and I really don't want to yell, but I will if I have to, so I think we should go outside because I don't want to wake up Diem.

Patrick Landry: We don't really want to hear what you have to say, Ledger. (motions toward the door) You should go.

Ledger Ward: (takes a deep breath) I've given my life to that little girl. You owe this to me. I'm not leaving your property until we talk about this.

Environment: The tension in the air is palpable as Ledger waits outside on the patio. The night is quiet, adding to the gravity of the moment.

Ledger Ward: (stands up as Patrick and Grace come outside) Every decision I make is for Diem. I ended my engagement with a woman I loved because I wasn't sure she would be good enough for that little girl. That should tell you that I would never put my own happiness before Diem's.

Ledger Ward: I know you both know that, and I also know you're just trying to protect yourselves from the pain Kenna's actions caused. But you're taking the worst moment of Kenna's life and you're making that moment who she is. That isn't fair. It isn't fair to Kenna. It isn't fair to Diem. I'm starting to wonder if it's even fair to Scotty.

Ledger Ward: (holds up the pages) She writes letters to him. To Scotty. She's been doing it for five years. This is the only one I've read, but it was enough to change my entire opinion of her.

Grace: (begins to cry)

Patrick Landry: (reaches for Grace and pulls her close)

Ledger Ward: We are keeping a mother from her child. That's not okay. Scotty would be so mad at us.

Ledger Ward: (hands Grace the letter) It'll be hard to read. But I'm not asking you to read it because I'm in love with Kenna. I'm asking you to read it because your son was in love with her.

Ledger Ward: I've given the last five years of my life to you guys. All I'm asking for in return is twenty minutes. It probably won't even take you that long to read the letter. After you read it, and take time to process it, we'll talk. And I'll respect whatever decisions the two of you make. I swear I will.

Ledger Ward: But please, please give me the next twenty minutes. You owe Diem the opportunity to have another person in her life who will love her as much as Scotty would have loved her.

Under the Dome-105-0.scenario: Inside the Dome, the air has become toxic and unbreathable. Julia Shumway and Dale Barbara are making a desperate attempt to breach the Dome using a makeshift breathing apparatus constructed from tires, garbage bags, and a hollow spindle. The situation is dire, with survivors like Sam struggling to breathe. The town's fate hangs in the balance as Julia prepares to approach a mysterious box that she believes might be key to lifting the Dome. Tension and fear permeate the air, mixing with hope that this risky plan might save them all.
Under the Dome-105-0.groundtruth:
Julia Shumway: This is all me. Just so you know that.

Dale Barbara: Yessum. It might help if I knew exactly what you had in mind.

Julia Shumway: There's nothing exact about it. All I have is intuition and a little hope.

Dale Barbara: Don't be such a pessimist. You've also got two tires, two garbage bags, and a hollow spindle.

Julia Shumway: (smiles) Duly noted.

Sam: (coughing heavily) Dear God and sonny Jesus, don't that taste nasty. Hurry up.

Dale Barbara: (punctures the tire with a knife) (jams the spindle into the hole)

Julia Shumway: (screams) What are you doing?

Dale Barbara: Trust me. Just go to the box and do what you have to do.

Julia Shumway: (stumbles to the flash-box and grips it)

Environment: Julia's back arches as she touches the box. Blood bursts from her nose and begins to trickle from the corner of her right eye.

Sam: (voice muffled and choked) What's happenin?

Dale Barbara: (prepares the second tire with the spindle)

Moby-Dick or, The Whale-139-0.scenario: The Pequod sails through treacherous waters on a bright, deceptively beautiful day. The air is thick with tension as the crew, exhausted from months at sea, mans their stations with nervous energy. The ship's wooden frame creaks under the strain of relentless pursuit. On the horizon, the ocean's surface remains unbroken, but all eyes scan for the telltale sign of their quarry. Captain Ahab, perched at his usual spot, grips the rail with white knuckles, his artificial leg of whalebone digging into the deck. The crew's fear is palpable, contrasting sharply with Ahab's manic determination.
Moby-Dick or, The Whale-139-0.groundtruth:
Ahab: D'ye see him? (shouting to the crew)

Crew: Not yet, sir!

Ahab: In his infallible wake, though; but follow that wake, that's all. Helm there; steady, as thou goest, and hast been going. What a lovely day again! were it a new-made world, and made for a summerhouse to the angels, and this morning the first of its throwing open to them, a fairer day could not dawn upon that world.

Starbuck: (to himself) Against the wind he now steers for the open jaw. God keep us, but already my bones feel damp within me, and from the inside wet my flesh. I misdoubt me that I disobey my God in obeying him!

Ahab: Stand by to sway me up! (to the crew) We should meet him soon.

Starbuck: Aye, aye, sir. (helps hoist Ahab up to the crow's nest)

Environment: A tense hour passes as the Pequod sails on, the crew anxiously watching for any sign of the white whale.

Ahab: (shouting triumphantly) Forehead to forehead I meet thee, this third time, Moby Dick! On deck there!—brace sharper up; crowd her into the wind's eye. He's too far off to lower yet, Mr. Starbuck.

Starbuck: Aye, Captain. (to the crew) You heard him, men! Brace up and crowd sail!

Ahab: Lower away!—Stand by the crew!

Environment: The whaleboats are lowered into the sea, with Ahab taking command of one. The chase begins in earnest as they row towards the surfacing Moby Dick.

Dead and Gone (Sookie Stackhouse, #9)-10.scenario: It's a quiet evening at Merlotte's bar. Sookie, still reeling from the traumatic werepanther punishment ritual, has been called into Sam's office. She's surprised to find Eric there too. The air is tense with unspoken emotions. Sam's office is small and cluttered, creating an intimate yet slightly claustrophobic atmosphere. The sounds of the bar are muffled through the closed door. Sookie feels cornered, knowing she'll have to confront her recent actions and feelings. Sam and Eric exchange worried glances, unsure how to approach the delicate situation.
Dead and Gone (Sookie Stackhouse, #9)-10.groundtruth:
Sam Merlotte: What's wrong? (Looks at Sookie with concern)

Sookie Stackhouse: (Takes a deep breath) I broke Calvin Norris's hand into bits. With a brick.

Sam Merlotte: Then he was... He stood up for your sister-in-law at the wedding.

Eric Northman: (Looks blank)

Sam Merlotte: (Explains impatiently) She had to break his hand, which represents his claws in panther form. She stood up for Jason.

Sookie Stackhouse: I don't belong to him. Did you think Eric coming would make me all happy and carefree?

Sam Merlotte: No, but I hoped it would help you talk about whatever was wrong.

Sookie Stackhouse: (Speaking quietly) Okay, what's wrong is that my brother arranged for Calvin and me to check on Crystal, who's about four months pregnant, and he fixed it so we'd get there at about the same time. And when we checked, we found Crystal in bed with Dove Beck. As Jason knew we would.

Eric Northman: And for this, you had to break the werepanther's fingers.

Sookie Stackhouse: Yes, Eric, that's what I had to do. I had to break my friend's fingers with a brick in front of a crowd.

Sam Merlotte: (Looking at Eric in exasperation) And I thought you'd be such a big help.

Left Behind (Left Behind, #1)-274-1.scenario: In Petra, a hidden city in Jordan, Rayford Steele's quarters serve as a gathering point for key figures of the Tribulation Force. The small shelter trembles with each booming meteorite impact, while outside, an unprecedented lightning storm illuminates the sky. The air is thick with tension and anticipation as the believers await the Glorious Appearing - the prophesied return of Jesus Christ. Meanwhile, the Unity Army, led by the Antichrist Nicolae Carpathia, is preparing to attack Petra. The world stands on the brink of the final battle between good and evil.
Left Behind (Left Behind, #1)-274-1.groundtruth:
Rayford Steele: Do we know the timing? I know we know what comes next, but do we know when?

Chaim Rosenzweig: We never have. I was one who thought the Glorious Appearing would be exactly seven years from the signing of the covenant between Antichrist and Israel, but clearly we were wrong about that. We know that following the phenomena in the sky comes the sign of His coming, but nothing tells us whether that will be immediate. God has His own timetable.

Rayford Steele: A thousand years is as a day, and all that.

Chaim Rosenzweig: And vice versa.

Environment: The booming of the meteorites shakes Rayford's little shelter, and as they increase in frequency, his bed moves.

Rayford Steele: (wincing in pain) Every injury feels worse. The anesthetic in my temple has worn off, and the pain is piercing and throbbing.

Mac McCullum: (entering the room) Nice show. But you ought to see it from a chopper.

Rayford Steele: You're breaking my heart. No, I want every detail. You going back out?

Mac McCullum: Thinkin' about it, pardner. Seems risky.

Rayford Steele: I'd think you'd be throwing caution to the wind at this point.

Mac McCullum: I want to be alive when it happens, Ray. That's all.

Environment: Lightning shoots from straight overhead to the ground, followed by an immediate resounding roar. The strike shakes the dwelling and echoes for half a minute among the surrounding mountains and hills.

Chaim Rosenzweig: Here we go. Keep your eyes on the heavens.

Flowers in the Attic (Dollanganger, #1)-.scenario: It's Christmas Eve at Foxworth Hall, and the family is gathered around an opulent Christmas tree in the grand living room. The atmosphere is tense, with forced cheerfulness masking underlying conflicts. Bart, the troubled son, has organized a lavish ball, but his erratic behavior has everyone on edge. Jory, paralyzed from a recent accident, has crafted a special gift for Bart - a handmade clipper ship. As presents are being exchanged, the family's fragile peace hangs by a thread, with unspoken secrets threatening to shatter their facade of holiday harmony.
Flowers in the Attic (Dollanganger, #1)-.groundtruth:
Jory Marquet: Bart, I didn't forget you. Cindy and Dad helped me wrap it once, but then I undid the wrapping, touched up again, wrapped it myself the last time after Cindy helped me lift it in. (looks around worriedly) Where the hell did it go, I wonder? It's a huge box, wrapped in red foil, tied with silver ribbons—and by far the largest box under the tree.

Cindy Sheffield: Oh, here it is, behind this red sofa. (carries the gift to Bart) For our lord, our master. (bows mockingly) I think Jory's a fool to give it to you after all the hard work he put into this thing, but maybe you'll be appreciative, for once.

Bart Winslow: (tears into the package, then suddenly pales) It's broken. Smashed to small pieces. There's nothing in this box but broken match-sticks and tangled rigging.

Environment: The room falls silent as Bart drops the box to the floor and kicks it aside. Tension fills the air as everyone waits for his next move.

Bart Winslow: (throws a hard look at Melodie) I should have known you would find the perfect way to repay me for sleeping with your wife.

Jory Marquet: (color draining from his face) I don't believe you, Bart. You've always had a nasty, hateful way of kicking where it hurts most.

Bart Winslow: I'm not lying. While you lay on your hospital bed, inside your cast, your wife and I shared one bed, and eagerly enough she spread her legs for me.

Christopher Dollanganger Jr.: (jumps to his feet, face angry) Bart, how dare you say such things to your brother? Apologize to Jory and Melodie, immediately! How can you hurt him like this, when already he's hurt enough? Do you hear me? You tell him every word you just said is a lie! A damned lie!

Bart Winslow: It's not a lie. If you never believe anything I say again, believe me when I say that Melodie was a very cooperative bed companion.

Cindy Sheffield: (jumps up and slaps Melodie's face) How dare you do that to Jory? You know how much he loves you!

Melodie Marquet: (rises awkwardly, trembling) Why can't you leave me alone? I'm not made of the same iron as the rest of you! I can't take one tragedy after another. Jory lay stricken in the hospital, unable to ever walk or dance again, and Bart was here. I needed someone. He held me, comforted me. I closed my eyes and pretended he was Jory.

Jory Marquet: (wiping away tears, forcing a weak smile) Well, now I know. I guessed a long time ago that she and Bart had something going on, but I hoped it was only my suspicions working overtime. But I should have known better. Mel can't live without a man beside her, especially in bed... and I can hardly blame her, can I?

Heir of Fire (Throne of Glass, #3)-42-0.scenario: In the opulent dining room of the glass castle, Celaena Sardothien, the newly appointed King's Champion, sits alone at a lavish table. The room is filled with tension and unspoken emotions following her recent breakup with Prince Dorian. Chaol Westfall, Captain of the Royal Guard, enters unexpectedly, his presence adding to the complex atmosphere. The air is thick with uncertainty and the weight of their shared history. Both characters are acutely aware of their positions within the royal court and the potential consequences of their actions.
Heir of Fire (Throne of Glass, #3)-42-0.groundtruth:
Celaena Sardothien: Two visits in one day? (raises her eyebrows) To what do I owe this pleasure?

Chaol Westfall: (frowns) Where's Dorian?

Celaena Sardothien: Why would Dorian be here?

Chaol Westfall: I thought he usually came here at this hour.

Celaena Sardothien: Well, don't expect to find him here after today.

Chaol Westfall: (approaches the table) Why?

Celaena Sardothien: (pops a piece of bread into her mouth) Because I ended it.

Chaol Westfall: You did what?

Celaena Sardothien: I'm the King's Champion. Surely you realize how inappropriate it would be for me to have a relationship with a prince.

Chaol Westfall: (fights a smile) I was wondering when you'd come to your senses.

Celaena Sardothien: Would you like to join me? (gestures to the table) It's a shame for me to celebrate alone.

Chaol Westfall: (pulls out a chair and sits down)

Celaena Sardothien: (fills a goblet with wine and hands it to Chaol) To four years until freedom.

Chaol Westfall: (raises his glass) To you, Celaena.

Environment: Their eyes meet, and a moment of understanding passes between them. The atmosphere is filled with a sense of possibility and cautious optimism.

The Assassin's Blade (Throne of Glass, #.scenario: On a blood-soaked battlefield, armies clash as magic crackles through the air. Aelin Galathynius has just turned the tide by revealing a surprise army of Fae and Wolf Tribe warriors. She stands with her mate Rowan Whitethorn, facing the ancient Valg queen Maeve. Lorcan, a powerful Fae warrior, supports them nearby. Fenrys, recently freed from Maeve's blood oath, struggles to recover from the devastating illusion he was trapped in. The air is thick with tension as the final confrontation begins, with the fate of their world hanging in the balance.
The Assassin's Blade (Throne of Glass, #.groundtruth:
Environment: The battlefield is a chaos of clashing armies, with the newly arrived Fae and Wolf Tribe warriors tearing into Morath's forces. Snow and blood mingle on the ground as magic crackles through the air.

Maeve: "I suppose you think you can now finish me off in some grand fashion," Maeve said to Aelin and Rowan, her dark power swelling. "You, who I have wronged the most."

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: (She blinks four times at Fenrys) "Look at me," she silently commands through their bond.

Fenrys: (His eyes blindly turn toward Aelin, clearing slightly)

Maeve: "Do you understand what a Valg queen is?" Maeve asked them, triumph on her face despite the chaos around them. "I am as vast and eternal as the sea. Erawan and his brothers sought me for my power."

Rowan Whitethorn Galathynius: (He tightens his grip on Aelin's hand, their magic fusing)

Maeve: (She lifts her arms, dark power flowing around her) "I am a god."

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: (She looks to Rowan, a silent understanding passing between them) "Together," she says quietly.

Rowan Whitethorn Galathynius: (He brushes his thumb against hers in a gesture of love and farewell)

Environment: Magic explodes as Aelin and Rowan unleash their combined power, white-hot flame roaring towards Maeve. The Valg queen counters with waves of darkness, only to be blocked by Lorcan's shield of black wind.

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: (Panting from the exertion) "I'd say that you haven't wronged us the most at all."

Fenrys: (He blinks once in response to Aelin, understanding her silent command)

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: (She flings out another wall of flame, pushing Maeve back) "But him—oh, he has a score to settle with you."

Maeve: (Her eyes go wide as she realizes the trap, but it's too late)

Fenrys: (He vanishes and reappears behind Maeve, Goldryn burning bright in his hands)

Environment: With a swift, decisive motion, Fenrys plunges Goldryn through Maeve's back and into her dark heart. The Valg queen's power falters as the blade strikes true, marking the end of her reign of terror.

The Story of My Life-29-0.scenario: The fifth meeting of the American Association to Promote the Teaching of Speech to the Deaf is underway at Mt. Airy, Philadelphia. The room is filled with educators, advocates, and families of deaf individuals. The atmosphere is charged with anticipation as Helen Keller, a remarkable deaf-blind woman who has learned to speak, takes the stage. The audience, aware of Helen's extraordinary journey, watches with a mix of curiosity and admiration. Helen, guided to the podium, stands tall, her face expressing determination and passion for her cause. The room falls silent as she prepares to address the gathering, her presence alone a testament to the power of perseverance and education.
The Story of My Life-29-0.groundtruth:
Helen Keller: If you knew all the joy I feel in being able to speak to you to-day, I think you would have some idea of the value of speech to the deaf, and you would understand why I want every little deaf child in all this great world to have an opportunity to learn to speak.

Helen Keller: I use speech constantly, and I cannot begin to tell you how much pleasure it gives me to do so. Of course I know that it is not always easy for strangers to understand me, but it will be by and by; and in the meantime I have the unspeakable happiness of knowing that my family and friends rejoice in my ability to speak.

Helen Keller: I can remember the time before I learned to speak, and how I used to struggle to express my thoughts by means of the manual alphabet—how my thoughts used to beat against my finger tips like little birds striving to gain their freedom, until one day Miss Fuller opened wide the prison-door and let them escape.

Helen Keller: I wonder if she remembers how eagerly and gladly they spread their wings and flew away. Of course, it was not easy at first to fly. The speech-wings were weak and broken, and had lost all the grace and beauty that had once been theirs; indeed, nothing was left save the impulse to fly, but that was something.

Helen Keller: One can never consent to creep when one feels an impulse to soar. But, nevertheless, it seemed to me sometimes that I could never use my speech-wings as God intended I should use them; there were so many difficulties in the way, so many discouragements; but I kept on trying, knowing that patience and perseverance would win in the end.

Helen Keller: And while I worked, I built the most beautiful air-castles, and dreamed dreams, the pleasantest of which was of the time when I should talk like other people; and the thought of the pleasure it would give my mother to hear my voice once more, sweetened every effort and made every failure an incentive to try harder next time.

Helen Keller: So I want to say to those who are trying to learn to speak and those who are teaching them: Be of good cheer. Do not think of today's failures, but of the success that may come to-morrow. You have set yourselves a difficult task, but you will succeed if you persevere.

Helen Keller: You will find a joy in overcoming obstacles—a delight in climbing rugged paths, which you would perhaps never know if you did not sometime slip backward—if the road was always smooth and pleasant.

Helen Keller: Remember, no effort that we make to attain something beautiful is ever lost. Sometime, somewhere, somehow we shall find that which we seek. We shall speak, yes, and sing, too, as God intended we should speak and sing.

Environment: As Helen finishes her speech, the audience sits in stunned silence, moved by her words and the power of her delivery. The room then erupts in applause, with many wiping tears from their eyes, inspired by Helen's courage and determination.

The Assassin's Blade (Throne of Glass, #.scenario: As Aelin's army approaches Endovier, the forest thins and the Ruhnn Mountains loom on the horizon. The air is thick with tension and unspoken memories. Aelin and Elide ride side by side, their horses' hooves echoing in the eerie quiet. The weight of their past experiences in captivity hangs heavily between them. The rest of the army follows behind, creating a somber procession. The rukhin patrol the skies, watchful for any signs of danger.
The Assassin's Blade (Throne of Glass, #.groundtruth:
Environment: The forest thins as Aelin and Elide ride side by side, the looming presence of the Ruhnn Mountains growing ever closer on the horizon.

Elide Lochan: I didn't think I'd really get to see Terrasen again, once Vernon took me out of Perranth.

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: There was a time when I thought I'd never see it again, too.

Elide Lochan: When you were an assassin, or when you were a slave?

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: Both. It was a torture of another kind, when I was at Endovier, to know that home was only miles away. And that I would not be able to see it one last time before I died.

Elide Lochan: I thought I'd die in that tower, and no one would remember that I had existed.

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: We made it out in the end, though.

Elide Lochan: (reaching over to squeeze Aelin's hand) Yes, we did.

Environment: The two women ride in companionable silence for a moment, the weight of their shared experiences hanging between them.

Aelin Ashryver Whitethorn Galathynius: (sighing softly)

Elide Lochan: (glancing at Aelin with concern)

Environment: Suddenly, a warning cry goes up from the rukhin, soaring along the edge between the forest and mountains.

The Help-36-0.scenario: The scene is set in the Leefolt home, a tense and oppressive environment during the segregated 1960s in Jackson, Mississippi. The living room feels claustrophobic, with Miss Hilly Holbrook standing authoritatively, Elizabeth Leefolt looking anxious and conflicted, and Aibileen Clark standing defensively, knowing her entire livelihood and reputation are at stake. The atmosphere is charged with racial tension, power dynamics, and the imminent threat of false accusation.
The Help-36-0.groundtruth:
Hilly Holbrook: Aibileen, when you returned my silver yesterday, there were three pieces missing out of that felt wrapper. One silver fork and two silver spoons.

Aibileen Clark: Lemme—lemme go look in the kitchen, maybe I left some behind. (Looks at Miss Leefolt for approval)

Hilly Holbrook: You know as well as I do that silver's not in the kitchen, Aibileen.

Aibileen Clark: Miss Leefolt, you checked in Ross's bed? He been sneaking things and sticking em—

Hilly Holbrook: (Scoffs loudly) Do you hear her, Elizabeth? She's trying to blame it on a toddler.

Aibileen Clark: Miss Leefolt, did you already check the kitchen? Or the silver closet? Miss Leefolt?

Hilly Holbrook: Aibileen, you can return those pieces to me by today, or else Elizabeth is going to press charges.

Elizabeth Leefolt: (Whispers) She says she doesn't have them, Hilly.

Hilly Holbrook: Then it behooves me to inform you that you are fired, Aibileen. (Sniffs) I'll be calling the police. They know me.

Aibileen Clark: Miss Hilly. (Says it loud and clear) I know something about you and don't you forget that.

Hilly Holbrook: (Narrows her eyes) Nobody would believe something you wrote, Nigra.

Aibileen Clark: I don't know. I been told I'm a pretty good writer.

Bleak House-67-0.scenario: In the comforting yet shadow-filled growlery of Bleak House, Esther Summerson and her guardian John Jarndyce sit surrounded by familiar volumes and the quiet ticking of a clock. The heavy drapes are partly drawn, letting in a muted light that speaks of subdued thoughts and earnest discussions. Having just recovered from a grave illness, Esther feels the warmth of her guardian's care as they settle into well-worn patterns of conversation. Yet the air is thick with unspoken concerns about the ongoing Jarndyce and Jarndyce lawsuit, Richard Carstone's vulnerability, and new arrangements for Mrs. Woodcourt's visit. The room, a haven of contemplation, acts as a cocoon where past and future threads of their lives interlace, threading hope through the fabric of uncertainty.
Bleak House-67-0.groundtruth:
John Jarndyce: "Dame Trot, welcome to the growlery again, my dear. I have a scheme to develop, little woman. I propose to remain here, perhaps for six months, perhaps for a longer time—as it may be. Quite to settle here for a while, in short."

Esther Summerson: "And in the meanwhile leave Bleak House?"

John Jarndyce: "Aye, my dear? Bleak House must learn to take care of itself. It is a long way from Ada, my dear, and Ada stands much in need of you."

Esther Summerson: "It's like you, guardian, to have been taking that into consideration for a happy surprise to both of us."

John Jarndyce: "Not so disinterested either, my dear, if you mean to extol me for that virtue. I wish to hear as much and as often of Ada as I can in this condition of estrangement from poor Rick. Not of her alone, but of him too, poor fellow."

Esther Summerson: "Have you seen Mr. Woodcourt, this morning, guardian?"

John Jarndyce: "I see Mr. Woodcourt every morning, Dame Durden."

Esther Summerson: "Does he still say the same of Richard?"

John Jarndyce: "Just the same. He knows of no direct bodily illness that he has; on the contrary, he believes that he has none. Yet he is not easy about him; who can be?"

Esther Summerson: "Dear, unfortunate, mistaken Richard. When will he awake from his delusion!"

John Jarndyce: "He is not in the way to do so now, my dear. The more he suffers, the more averse he will be to me, having made me the principal representative of the great occasion of his suffering."

Environment: The conversation continues, touching on Mrs. Woodcourt's stay and Mr. Woodcourt's future plans. The room is filled with a mixture of concern, affection, and cautious optimism as Esther and Jarndyce discuss these important matters.

Switched (Trylle, #1)-68-0.scenario: Dans le palais royal des Trylles, Wendy, récemment couronnée reine, se prépare à une conversation difficile avec Finn, son ancien intérêt amoureux. L'atmosphère est tendue, chargée d'émotions non dites et de changements imminents. La salle du trône, symbole du nouveau statut de Wendy, sert de toile de fond à cette rencontre. Les conseillers et gardes ont été congédiés, laissant les deux personnages seuls pour cette discussion cruciale. L'air est lourd de responsabilités royales et de décisions personnelles qui auront un impact sur l'avenir du royaume.
Switched (Trylle, #1)-68-0.groundtruth:
Wendy Everly: Finn, je sais que tu es en colère, mais il faut que tu comprennes. Je... j'aime Loki.

Finn Holmes: Tu le connais à peine, Wendy. Comment peux-tu être sûre ?

Wendy Everly: Je sais. Je ne sais pas comment l'expliquer, mais... c'est ainsi. Il me pousse à être meilleure, à prendre des risques pour le royaume.

Finn Holmes: Et moi ? Je n'ai jamais voulu que le meilleur pour toi.

Wendy Everly: Je sais, Finn. Mais tu n'as jamais vraiment lutté pour moi. Tu as toujours accepté les règles, les traditions, sans essayer de les changer.

Finn Holmes: (Baisse les yeux) Tu as raison. Je n'ai jamais vraiment essayé de changer les choses.

Wendy Everly: Je me bats pour changer les choses ici, pour améliorer la vie des pisteurs et des autres Trylles. J'ai besoin de quelqu'un qui me soutienne dans ce combat.

Finn Holmes: Et tu penses que Loki est cette personne ?

Wendy Everly: Oui, je le crois. Il me pousse à être meilleure, à prendre des risques pour le bien du royaume.

Finn Holmes: (Soupire profondément) Je suis désolé, Wendy. Tu as raison. Je ne me suis jamais vraiment battu pour toi comme j'aurais dû le faire.

Wendy Everly: Je suis désolée aussi, Finn. J'espère que tu pourras trouver le bonheur.

Finn Holmes: Du moment que tu es heureuse, Wendy. C'est tout ce qui compte.

The Idiot-49-0.scenario: In a richly decorated sitting room, the atmosphere is tense and charged with anticipation. The room is dimly lit by a single chandelier, casting shadows that dance along the walls adorned with ornate patterns. A large window offers a view of the rain-soaked streets of St. Petersburg, reflecting the internal turmoil. It's the night before the grand wedding, but a storm rages outside and within, mirroring Nastasya Filippovna's conflicted heart. The setting is both physically and emotionally stormy, drawing all attention to the couple seated amidst opulence, yet seemingly isolated by their private crisis.
The Idiot-49-0.groundtruth:
Nastasya Filippovna: (falls to her knees before the prince, crying) What am I doing! What am I doing! What am I doing to you!

Prince Lev Nikolaevich Myshkin: (kneels down beside her, speaking softly) Nastasya Filippovna, please don't cry. Tell me what's troubling you.

Nastasya Filippovna: (looks up at him with tear-filled eyes) I'm ruining your life, Prince. You deserve so much better than me. I'm tainted, broken.

Prince Lev Nikolaevich Myshkin: (gently takes her hands) You're not ruining anything. I love you, Nastasya Filippovna. You're precious to me, just as you are.

Nastasya Filippovna: But what about your reputation? The scandal? Everyone will look down on you because of me.

Prince Lev Nikolaevich Myshkin: (speaks with quiet determination) I don't care about reputation or what others think. I care about you, about us. Nothing else matters.

Nastasya Filippovna: (stands up, pacing nervously) But what if I hurt you? What if I can't be the wife you deserve?

Prince Lev Nikolaevich Myshkin: (stands and approaches her carefully) Nastasya Filippovna, I accept you fully, with all your past and all your fears. We'll face the future together.

Nastasya Filippovna: (turns to face him, vulnerability in her eyes) Do you really believe we can be happy, Prince? That I won't destroy everything?

Prince Lev Nikolaevich Myshkin: (takes her hands gently) I believe in us, Nastasya Filippovna. Our love is stronger than any obstacle. Trust in that, in me, in yourself.

Nastasya Filippovna: (embraces the prince, still trembling slightly) Thank you, my dear Prince. I'll try. For you, for us, I'll try to be brave.

Prince Lev Nikolaevich Myshkin: (holds her close, stroking her hair) That's all I ask, my love. We'll face everything together, one day at a time.

The Other Boleyn Girl (The Plantagenet a.scenario: It's a somber May morning in 1536 at the Tower of London. A crowd has gathered on Tower Green to witness the unprecedented execution of Queen Anne Boleyn. The air is thick with tension and whispered speculation. A wooden scaffold stands ominously in the center, surrounded by guards. Among the onlookers is Mary Boleyn, Anne's sister, barely able to comprehend the tragedy unfolding before her. The Other Boleyn Girl (The Plantagenet a.groundtruth:
Environment: A scaffold has been erected on Tower Green. A crowd has gathered to witness the execution of Queen Anne Boleyn. The atmosphere is tense and somber.

Mary Boleyn: (Scans the crowd anxiously, looking for any sign of a royal messenger)

Anne Boleyn: (Walks to the scaffold with grace, her head held high)

Environment: Anne Boleyn climbs the steps to the scaffold. She removes her cloak and headdress, handing them to her ladies-in-waiting.

Anne Boleyn: Good Christian people, I am come hither to die, for according to the law, and by the law I am judged to die, and therefore I will speak nothing against it.

Mary Boleyn: (Looks around desperately, her heart pounding)

Anne Boleyn: I pray God save the king and send him long to reign over you, for a gentler nor a more merciful prince was there never: and to me he was ever a good, a gentle and sovereign lord.

Environment: The crowd murmurs, some moved by Anne's words, others unmoved. The executioner stands ready, his sword gleaming in the morning light.

Mary Boleyn: (Clenches her fists, willing a royal messenger to appear)

Anne Boleyn: And if any person will meddle of my cause, I require them to judge the best. And thus I take my leave of the world and of you all, and I heartily desire you all to pray for me.

Environment: Anne kneels on the scaffold, her ladies helping to blindfold her. The crowd falls silent, tension thick in the air.

Mary Boleyn: (Stares in horror as the executioner raises his sword)

Environment: The executioner's sword flashes in the sunlight, swiftly descending. With a single stroke, Anne Boleyn's head is severed from her body.

Mary Boleyn: (Stifles a scream, tears streaming down her face)

The Gunslinger (The Dark Tower, #1)-95-0.groundtruth:

Last Sacrifice (Vampire Academy, #6)-137.scenario: At the royal Moroi Court, Lissa Dragomir and her friends gather in a private room to meet with Ambrose, Queen Tatiana's former companion.
